page.title: 14Coast - Macduff Castle
page.content: On the cliffs between East Wemyss and Buckhaven stands the ruins of Macduff Castle. Although now in ruins the castle was for many years the seat of government in the Parish of Wemyss. Traditionally, the building is connected with Macduff, Thane of Fife, the slayer of the evil Macbeth. (1057 AD). Macduff's Castle is undoubtedly one of the oldest maritime fortresses of the great Earls of Fife. The present Castle dates back to the early 14th Century, however, there was probably a wooden castle on this site as early as the 11th Century. In 1630 the Castle and a large section of land was sold to John, the 1st Earl of Wemyss. The Castle was in excellent repair at this time and the Earl made it his cheif residence. The Castle was last known to be inhabited in 1666 but could have been lived in after this.
